title: 4 Ways to Clean a Glass Stove Top & How to Prevent Scratches

steps.title: Make a vinegar and water solution to remove burn marks and stains.
steps.content: Make a vinegar and water solution to remove burn marks and stains. This is a cheap, natural cleanser. Mix a 1:1 solution of distilled white vinegar and water. Pour it into a spray bottle and spray a generous layer over the entire stovetop. If you see any food build-up, grease, or burn marks let the solution sit on those areas for 10-15 minutes before wiping the stove top surface with a clean, damp microfiber cloth. [1] X Research source Make sure the stove top is turned off and cold to the touch before using any type of cleaner on it.

steps.title: Use a baking soda and water paste to remove baked-on food.
steps.content: Use a baking soda and water paste to remove baked-on food. Sprinkle baking soda over a stove top, then lay a microfiber cloth soaked in warm water or a 1:1 vinegar and water cleaning solution over it. Leave it for 15-30 minutes, then rinse the cloth out in and use it to scrub the baking soda into the stove top. Finish by wiping the surface clean with a soft sponge soaked in cold water. [2] X Research source For stains that just won't lift, let the baking soda sit for 30 minutes before cleaning it up. [3] X Research source If the food doesn't come loose after you follow the above steps, spray the stain with water or a homemade vinegar solution. Next, use a wet razor blade or wet pumice stone to carefully scrape up the food particles. Work the blade or pumice in one direction only to avoid scratches.

steps.title: Use The Pink Stuff to remove baked-on food without a scraper.
steps.content: Use The Pink Stuff to remove baked-on food without a scraper. This cleanser is mildly abrasive, which is perfect for helping you lift all those stuck pieces of food. To use, scoop a thumb-sized amount of The Pink Stuff onto a damp sponge. Then work it into the stove top in circular motions, giving special attention to greasy areas and baked-on food. Rinse out the sponge and use it to wipe the stove top clean. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Use Bar Keepers Friend to clean hard water deposits.
steps.content: Use Bar Keepers Friend to clean hard water deposits. Dampen a sponge and rub the Bar Keepers Friend powder into the stove top using circular motions. Let the powder sit for 1 minute before rinsing out your sponge and then rubbing it or a damp microfiber cloth over the stove top to remove the cleanser residue. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Apply a glass stovetop polish to the scratches.
steps.content: Apply a glass stovetop polish to the scratches. First, clean the surface with the cleanser of your choice (like Bar Keepers Friend), then apply the stovetop polish and buff it with a microfiber cloth, working in circular motions. Clean up the excess polish with a clean, damp cloth. [6] X Research source If you don't want to buy or can't find glass stovetop polish, use car wax instead and follow the same process as above.

steps.title: Clean your glass stove top daily or after each use to prevent stain buildup.
steps.content: Clean your glass stove top daily or after each use to prevent stain buildup. Use your cleanser of choice along with a soft sponge or microfiber cloth. Reserve scrubbing with baking soda paste and scraping with a razor or pumice stone for particularly stubborn messes. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid cleaning the glass with harsh chemicals, steel wool, and rough objects.
steps.content: Avoid cleaning the glass with harsh chemicals, steel wool, and rough objects. Rough objects include stiff sponges, paper towels, and scouring pads, as these can all etch the glass surface of your stove top. Harsh chemical cleaners like bleach and ammonia-based cleaners like Lysol can also damage the glass. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Angle the razor blade or pumice stone low when scraping and keep it wet.
steps.content: Angle the razor blade or pumice stone low when scraping and keep it wet. These tips – as well as ensuring the stove top is also wet – will prevent scratches according to cleaning expert Ashley Matuska.

steps.title: Ensure your cookware is clean before placing it on the stove top.
steps.content: Ensure your cookware is clean before placing it on the stove top. If food is still stuck to the bottom of a pot or a pan, it may have hardened and become sharp enough to scratch the glass when you set it down or move it. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Lift your pots and pans to move them instead of sliding them.
steps.content: Lift your pots and pans to move them instead of sliding them. This will prevent scratches and abrasions caused by the friction between the cookware and the glass surface of your stove top. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Try not to drop anything hard or sharp on your stove top.
steps.content: Try not to drop anything hard or sharp on your stove top. Any sharp, hard, or heavy dish or utensil can leave a mark on your glass stove top when dropped on it from a height. [11] X Research source
